message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with a severe case of ulcerative colitis, which can lead to toxic megacolon. A plain abdominal radiograph can help confirm the diagnosis of toxic megacolon and determine the need for urgent surgical intervention. Abdominal CT with IV contrast is not the first line imaging modality for this condition. Colectomy is a possible treatment, but only after the severity of the condition has been established. Contrast enema is not practical in this case as it carries a risk of perforation.

The next best step in management is plain abdominal radiograph to evaluate for toxic megacolon. Abdominal CT with IV contrast may be helpful if plain abdominal radiograph is inconclusive or if perforation is suspected. Colectomy is a drastic option that is typically reserved for severe cases or when there is no response to medical management. Contrast enema is not recommended in the acute setting due to the risk of perforation.

We refer to medical resources for help. The patient's symptoms, history of ulcerative colitis, and laboratory values suggest acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease. Plain abdominal radiograph is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for evaluating patients with suspected acute colonic inflammation. It will help identify any features that suggest colonic dilatation or obstruction, which are indications for urgent intervention such as colectomy. Abdominal CT with IV contrast may be necessary in cases where the plain radiograph is equivocal or further evaluation of the extent and severity of colonic inflammation is required. Contrast enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon.

Abdominal CT may also be helpful but is not the next best step as it requires more time and is not as readily available. Colectomy is a treatment option but should not be considered until the diagnosis is confirmed. Contrast enema is not recommended in the presence of suspected perforation as it may worsen the condition.
